posts.name: mikets
posts.cooked: Is there a way to detect lost comm in code? We would like to log the event and do some orderly shutdown instead of the robot being out-of-control.

posts.name: Brendan R.
posts.cooked:
I believe DriverStation.isDSAttached is what you are looking for

https://first.wpi.edu/wpilib/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/DriverStation.html#isDSAttached()

There is also an equivalent for if the FMS is attached.

posts.name: mikets
posts.cooked: isDSAttached has potential but isFMSAttached is probably not appropriate becasue FMS is not attached unless you are in real competition. We want this code to run regardless of the robot in competition or just practiciing. Are there any unforeseen scenarios that isDSAttached returns false but we did not lose comm?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
isDSAttached() will return false until the DS attaches (e.g. when the code first boots).

Regarding loss of control, the NetComm background process on the Rio will automatically disable motors etc based on loss of comm from the DS .  You do not need to implement this functionality in your code.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
IsDsAttached takes ~5 seconds to time out. The best thing to check is RobotController.isSysActive(). If that is false, there is either no DS connected or the DS packet watchdog has timed out.

However, as Peter said all motor controller devices are required to also respond to this, and disable themselves if that value is ever false.

posts.name: mikets
posts.cooked: Thanks for the info. No, we weren’t concern about shutting off the motors. We just want to prep the robot that we won’t get pushed or damaged. We have something we called “Turtle mode” that the robot will retract all appendages. In our last match, we lost comm because we got hit hard and another team deliberately took advantage of it and pushed us into their Source Zone giving us the penalty they needed to win the game by 2 points. So, the question is, do we get a chance to do a last command to the motors before the background process shut us down? BTW, if there is a background process that shuts down the motors, then why did we have out-of-control robots in previous seasons that the FTA had to emergency shut down a robot to prevent field damage?

posts.name: mikets
posts.cooked:
The description of isSysActive is: Gets a value indicating whether the FPGA outputs are enabled. The outputs may be disabled if the robot is disabled or e-stopped, the watchdog has expired, or if the roboRIO browns out.

robotRIO browns out may be a frequent event especially with the new Kraken. We could unnecessarily shut ourselves down checking this, couldn’t we? Or do you think the brownout is severe enough to reboot the radio anyway. This may be tricky because on the other hand, if the robot could recover from the lost comm, we would like to have the robot come back to live and operable. So, the question is: when isSysActive returns false, would the background process also transition the robot from either TeleOp or Auto mode to Disabled mode? And would it transition the robot back to the corresponding mode when comm recovers? If it would, the robot can also have code to prep for recovery.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
mikets:

So, the question is, do we get a chance to do a last command to the motors before the background process shut us down?

Nope. No actuation without comms and an enabled robot. The motors themselves enforce this via CAN heartbeats from the Rio. You can change motor settings such as brake or coast mode while disabled though, and potentially enable a minor escape hatch (like letting arms fall down to safer positions via gravity). Pnuematics can also be abused for this, as single-action solenoids will be reset to “normally closed” on disable, potentially creating a free actuation.

mikets:

BTW, if there is a background process that shuts down the motors, then why did we have out-of-control robots in previous seasons that the FTA had to emergency shut down a robot to prevent field damage?

There’s a difference between “lost comms” and “the robot is behaving unexpectedly”. Lost comms automatically disables the bot and all motors. Code or mechanical faults causing errant behaviour does not. The strategic truth is that when given a choice, drivers do not e-stop their bots. With an e-stop, you forfeit any chance to regain control, even at a diminished level. You also set your bot up for significant foul points should you get nudged into foul zones. If there’s any actual safety concerns, the FTAs handle it. Drive teams are focusing on strategic concerns, and that’s “do literally anything but die on the field”.

posts.name: mikets
posts.cooked: Brake mode doesn’t lock wheels, it just gives it some resistance, so the robot still can be pushed.

posts.name: mikets
posts.cooked:
Drive teams are focusing on strategic concerns, and that’s “do literally anything but die on the field”.

With the exception of remaining GP and that the rules allow.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: The robot mode stays in the current mode even when that returns false. That’s the only way to detect a potential disconnect state. All other methods take 5 seconds. And once that is false, you can’t command motors anymore, they’re all automatically disabled.

posts.name: mikets
posts.cooked: What about when comm recovers? When comm was lost and recovered, our event logging always started a new file. This only happens when robot mode starts.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked: If comms were lost for more than 5 seconds, robot code will move to disabled. That will coencide with IsDSAttached returning false. Then when reconnected, your robot will go back into teleop.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
